don't add any sweeteners or artificial coloring, juniper berries, spices, angelica plant roots, coriander seeds, lemon, and cardamom.
212 degrees will ruin the batch by evaporation. throughout the distillation process samples are taken. the middle of each batch know as the heart of the distillation is collected. its filtered and diluted to 43%. bottles are filled by hand, six at one time. the consumer pulls a small gold tab to remove the seal and uncork the bottle. this is a London dry gin, w/ traditional ingredients and contains no added sweeteners or coloring.

This is not how gin was made before large distillery. Buying cheap alcohol and adding a flavor to it is lame at best. You don't get the best flavor that way. The mash has to have the flavor before and after the first run its done twice. My dad had pot stills in every garage we had. He made white dog, gin, brandy. My grampa made dago red wine. He also made his own vinegar. As kids we got to stomp them grapes. Hell leave the berries in it long enough and you can make anything have a flavor. I'll pass.

1 God, who at sundry times and in divers manners spake in time past unto the fathers by the prophets,

Piger Henricus gin is named for the dark age alchemist's furnace; the term is Latin and translates as "Slow" or "Lazy Harry"... so presumably a term of endearment.
The gin itself is in the traditional London dry style, suggesting a juniper-forward flavor for classic cocktails (especially the timeless Martini).

The Subversive Distillers are located in Quebec, Canada founded by Pascal Gervais, Fernando Balthazar, Robert Paradis, and Stephen Roffo.

The bottles retail for around $26USD, overseas in the UK, 40.
